conversation.text: Hi! The task we will be doing now is chatting. I will be answering any questions you have about cooking. What would you like to cook?
Hello. I'm feeling like something sweet. Do you have any recipes for that?
I've got the perfect recipe which doubles as a fun activity! Do you want to make rock candy on a string?
evidence: forming your rock candy crystals

conversation.text: Yes. That sounds yummy. What do I need to begin and how long will it take?

You will need a large enough glass jar, natural fiber string like twine or cotton, something to tie the string to such as a pencil, butter knife, skewer or popsicle stick, sugar, water, wax paper, a weight for the string, and you may even want a piece of rock candy. Do you have the necessary materials and ingredients?
evidence: string around the middle of a pencil and tie a weight (such as a paperclip)
bottom of the glass.
string made from natural fiber, like twine or cotton
washer or screw to weight the string, or even another piece of rock candy
butter knife, skewer, or popsicle stick instead. A butter knife or popsicle stick may be more stable
sugar/water
wax paper to dry
Wait one week for crystals to form

conversation.text: Yes, I have everything. How long will it take?
It will take about one week. What sort of string do you have and what will you be tying it to? Will you be using a string weight?
evidence: Wait one week for crystals to form

conversation.text: I'm using twine, a butter knife, and I have a weight. What's the first step?
Tie one end of your string to the centre of your butterknife and tie your weight to the other end of the string. How long is your string?
evidence: Tie one end of a string around the middle of a pencil and tie a weight (such as a paperclip) to the other end.

conversation.text: Got it. The string is about the length of the glass. Should I cut the string shorter?
Yes. Cut it so that it's 2/3 the length of the glass and the weight doesn't touch the bottom.
evidence: string should be about 2/3 as long as the glass is deep

conversation.text: Alright, the string has been cut and tied. What's next?
Can your butter knife sit flat across the top of the glass?
evidence: pencil should be long enough that it can rest on the top of the glass without falling in

conversation.text: Yes. Should I prepare the water and sugar mixture now?
Yes. Once it is prepared, you can dip the string into the solution, then take it out and lay it to dry.
evidence: Dip the string in the glass of sugar/water solution, remove it, and lay on a piece of wax paper to dry

conversation.text: Ok, I dipped the string in. Where should I put the string out to dry?
Lay the string on wax paper to dry.
evidence: lay on a piece of wax paper to dry

conversation.text: Done. Is there anything I can do to prepare for the next step while the string dries?
You can try to speed the process up by rolling the wet string in granulated sugar to create the seed crystals. Is your string lying straight on the wax paper?
evidence: Lay the string out straight, since it will become stiff as it dries

conversation.text: That seems like it will be a bit messy. I think I'll just let the string dry by itself. How will I know that I created seed crystals?
Is your string stiff? Do you see some crystals forming on the drying string?
evidence: As the water evaporates, you will see a few crystals form on the string
stiff as it dries

conversation.text: Yes, I do! How exciting! I hope this turns out well so I can show my sister. She'll be really surprised. I think it's dried. What's next?
Place the string into the water and rest the butter knife on top. The string should not touch any part of the glass.
evidence: Lower the string into the glass of sugar/water solution, resting the pencil on the top of the glass.
string should hang straight down and never come in contact with the bottom or sides of the glass

conversation.text: I've done that. Should I cover the glass?
Yes, you can cover it with a paper towel to allow the water to evaporate. This process is really important to forming the candy crystals!
evidence: Cover the solution with a paper towel.

conversation.text: Am I done for now? Do you I just need to wait for the candy to form?
You're almost done this step. Just to check, is your string hanging straight down without touching the glass?
evidence: string should hang straight down and never come in contact with the bottom or sides of the glass

conversation.text: Yes it is. I wonder what would happen if it were touching the glass. I should run a parallel experiment!
Do you care if you get big crystals, or do you prefer for your crystals to grow faster?
evidence: glass somewhere safe, where it will remain undisturbed
cool, dark space, where the water will evaporate slowly, giving the crystals lots of time to grow
grow crystals quickly, but don't care if they get big, put the glass in a sunny spot

conversation.text: Big crystals would look prettier, I bet. How do I get bigger crystals?
Put your glass in a cool and dark space.
evidence: biggest crystals, look for a cool, dark space, where the water will evaporate slowly

conversation.text: I've got the perfect spot in a cabinet. Is there anything else I need to be aware of before I leave it to grow?
Yes. Try not to disturb the crystals while they grow. Is your glass away from loud noise sources like the tv or vibrations from people moving?
evidence: Keep your glass off the ground (and away form the vibrations of people walking on the floor
away from sources of music or noise, like a stereo or television.
Don't touch or tap the glass,

conversation.text: I think I should move the glass to the basement. People might open and close the cabinet door and disturb the crystals. When will I know it's done?
When you see big and smooth crystals on the string? Do you see these crystals?
evidence: After a week you should see big, smooth crystals on the string.

conversation.text: Yes. Can I eat the candy now?
Yes. You can cut the weight from the string and enjoy!
evidence: Snip the paperclip off with scissors

conversation.text: Thank you! It tastes delicious.

recipe.title: How to Make Rock Candy on a String

procedure.summary: Tie one end of a string around the middle of a pencil and tie a weight (such as a paperclip) to the other end.
procedure.description: The paperclip will act as a weight and keep your string hanging straight down so it doesn't touch the sides. The string should be about 2/3 as long as the glass is deep--it should not be long enough that the weight will touch the bottom of the glass. This will give your crystals plenty of space to grow. Touching or hanging too close to the bottom or sides of the glass could make your crystals smaller or misshapen. Use a string made from natural fiber, like twine or cotton. Fishing twine or nylon string are too smooth and it will be difficult for the sugar crystals to find crevices to cling to and grow. You can also use a washer or screw to weight the string, or even another piece of rock candy, which may help your crystals grow faster. The pencil should be long enough that it can rest on the top of the glass without falling in. You can also use a butter knife, skewer, or popsicle stick instead. A butter knife or popsicle stick may be more stable, as they can lay flat on top of the glass and won't roll.

procedure.summary: Dip the string in the glass of sugar/water solution, remove it, and lay on a piece of wax paper to dry.
procedure.description: Lay the string out straight, since it will become stiff as it dries. As the water evaporates, you will see a few crystals form on the string. These are seed crystals and they will help larger crystals grow around these points. You must make sure the string is completely dry before you proceed to the next step and be very careful not to knock off any of the seed crystals when you place the string in the solution. You can skip this step or try to speed it along by wetting the string and rolling it in granulated sugar (just make sure the string is completely dry before you put it in the glass and the sugar isn't falling off), but making seed crystals will make your rock candy grow faster and increase your chances of success in growing crystals.

procedure.summary: Lower the string into the glass of sugar/water solution, resting the pencil on the top of the glass.
procedure.description: The string should hang straight down and never come in contact with the bottom or sides of the glass. Cover the solution with a paper towel. You don't want to seal the glass with something that will keep the air out, like plastic wrap, as evaporation is an essential part of this process. As the water evaporates, the remaining solution becomes more saturated with sugar, and the water must force the sugar out. The sugar molecules will collect on the string, forming your rock candy crystals. Tape the pencil to the jar to keep it from rolling or moving while your crystals form.

procedure.summary: Place the glass somewhere safe, where it will remain undisturbed.
procedure.description: For the biggest crystals, look for a cool, dark space, where the water will evaporate slowly, giving the crystals lots of time to grow. If you want to grow crystals quickly, but don't care if they get big, put the glass in a sunny spot so that the water evaporates quickly. Vibrations can negatively affect your crystal growth. Keep your glass off the ground (and away form the vibrations of people walking on the floor) and away from sources of music or noise, like a stereo or television.

procedure.summary: Wait one week for crystals to form.
procedure.description: Don't touch or tap the glass, or you may disturb the crystal growth and even cause some to fall off the string. After a week you should see big, smooth crystals on the string.

procedure.summary: Carefully remove the string from the solution and lay it on wax paper to dry.
procedure.description: Snip the paperclip off with scissors. If the rock candy is stuck to the glass, run some hot water on the bottom of the glass. This should loosen the sugar enough so that you can pull your candy out without damaging it.
